title: Phillip Schofield clashes with Extinction Rebellion over Tube protest
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Phillip Schofield butted heads with a representative for Extinction Rebellion over their protest at Canning Town Tube station on Thursday morning.

In shocking footage released this morning, angry commuters were filmed dragging a protester off the roof of the train before attacking them in a flurry of kicks and punches.

Extinction Rebellion coordinator Sarah Lunnon appeared on Thursday’s This Morning to talk about the group’s actions.

Phillip argued that the commuters’ frustration was understandable as they were trying to get to work.

Sarah explained that the ‘point of this particular action was to identify the fragility of the systems that we’re working with. The fragility of our transport systems.’

Phil said: ‘We know that. If there’s a power cut we know it’s fragile. You don’t need to prove that to us. What you’ve done is you’ve stopped ordinary people going to work. Some of them workers whose families will depend on an hourly rate of the money that they make. You’ve surely shot yourself in the foot.’

Sarah said that she ‘could understand’ the disruption caused and the impact it can have, and Phil attempted to ask another question.

Phillip Schofield said Sarah was making the same point multiple times (Picture: ITV)

Sarah told him: ‘Phillip would you like me to answer your question or would you like to talk over me?’

Phil replied: ‘There’s no reason to get like that. We’ve got a lot to get in now and you’ve actually made that point unless you want to make it multiple times.’

He also addressed the fact that people then left the Tube station and got in cabs to get to work. Sarah argued that the point of the action was not to have ‘a beneficial environmental impact’ but ‘to highlight the disruption that is going to happen to our very, very fragile systems’.

Sarah Lunnon explained the action was to reveal the ‘fragility of our transport systems’ (Picture: ITV/REX)

Presenter Holly Willoughby added that the fact there will be no further London Underground disruptions today could be seen as an admission that they had ‘got it wrong’.

Sarah argued: ‘I don’t think we’ve got it wrong necessarily because today I’m sitting in this studio and we’ve been bumped three times from This Morning studios in the last 10 days. And it’s taken us being this disruptive to get on your programme to talk about the emergency we are facing.’

Phil cut in: ‘Is that why you do it?’, and Sarah laughed before pressing on with her point.

This Morning airs weekdays from 10.30am on ITV.
